body.p: Shakespeare never grows old.He continues to inspire each new generation. Is this true?Is Shakespeare really never getting old and always interesting to a new generation?

p.s: The most argument you will hear against this will be, that Shakespeare is simply boring to the new generations.
They more like things like video games or action movies.
But, ShakespearesShakespeare's plays cover mostly timeless topics like love or funny stuff.
Of course, things that were funny back then probably are not funny anymore today, but topics like love are still relevant in todaystoday's movies or books.
Also, many modern things already include things from Shakespeare without us knowing.
For example, he integrated many words into the modern englishEnglish assasinassassin, used in the video game Assasins CreedAssassin's Creed.
You can encounter now, that Shakespeare is way harder to understand while reading or consuming in any way, because of the old grammar and the old language used.
This is totally correct, but you are given a lot of help while trying to understand it.
Most of the old phrases or words are explained to you in modern English.
Another argument against still teaching Shakespeare in school is that it does not really bringsbring the students forward.
What are the benefits of reading that old plays or books?
They could help you to understand other older plays or books.
Also, if you once understood how to read or understand the old grammar and language, you could use it somewhere else.
For me as a student, it is not really super important or boring.
Of course it is interesting to see where in our modern language Shakespeare hides but otherwise I also could image more interesting topics.
To answer the question, I think Shakespeare should be teached in school, but maybe in a more interesting way like searching for Shakespeare signs in modern movies etc.
